snippet: At a meeting with the advocates for disabled people, New York State’s Medicaid director vowed to hold plans accountable when it came to enrolling the most seriously impaired seniors, participants said.
abstract: Legal advocates for the disabled tell New York State's Medicaid director Jason A Helgerson that managed care companies are signing up healthier older adults referred to them, but deterring the most seriously impaired people from enrolling in a plan; issues underscore difficulties as Gov Andrew M Cuomo, through Department of Health, moves tens of thousands of Medicaid recipients who need long-term care into managed-care plans.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting with the advocates for disabled people, New York State’s Medicaid director vowed to hold plans accountable when it came to enrolling the most seriously impaired seniors, participants said.

headline.seo: Advocates Say N.Y. Managed-Care Plans Shun the Most Disabled Seniors
headline.main: Advocates Say Managed-Care Plans Shun the Most Disabled Medicaid Users
headline.print_headline: Advocates Say Managed-Care Plans Shun the Most Disabled Medicaid Users
